revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{advert|date=January 2016}} {{notability|date=January 2016}} {{unreferenced|date=January 2016}} {{Orphan|date=January 2017}} }}
[[File:Mathgameslogo.gif|thumbnail|Math-GAMES is a transnational project, co-financed by the [[European Commission]] DG Education&Culture under the No. 2015-1-DE02-KA204-002260 ]]
The '''Math-GAMES''' is an educational project in the framework of the program "Erasmus+" by the [[European Commission]], which presents free material for lessons and training of teachers, to teach pupils [[Mathematics]] through [[games]], mostly traditional games like [[chess]], [[checkers]] or [[Nine Men's Morris|mill]].
Partners in the project are participants from [[Germany]], [[Italy]], [[Spain]], [[Romania]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Turkey]], [[France]], [[Greece]] and [[Cyprus]].
The project "Math-GAMES - Games And Mathematics in Education for Adults – Compendiums, Guidelines and Courses for Numeracy Learning Methods Based on Games" is producing a compendium and a guidebook in 9 languages, which should give the answer to two main questions while rising numeracy in education:
* How can we reduce the number of under skilled adults to promote social integration and participation into our society? * How can we increase incentives for adult training by using games? * How can we offer tailored learning opportunities to individual learners by using games? * How can we provide information on access to the services of adult learning? * How can we save traditional and famous games in different countries from a loss?
During the project, the project partners will collect real examples, in which playing traditional games could bring low-skilled people out of isolation and helps participating in our society. In this part the mobility of trainers is necessary. In parts normal skilled people will play these games together with lower-skilled persons. The results are the "Math-GAMES Compendium of Famous Traditional Games", which are books in 9 languages (BG, DE, EN, ES, FR, GR, IT, RO, TR).
After that the partners of the project will prove, how traditional games could be implemented in their learning program for a better understanding, especially for lower-skilled people. The result are the “Math-GAMES Numeracy Learning Guidelines” in 9 languages (BG, DE, EN, ES, FR, GR, IT, RO, TR).
At the third part of the project the project partners will prove by doing and testing during real courses and seminars that playing games between people with different skills assist the social integration and thus traditional games will be saved from a loss by transferring it to other people. The result is a "Math-GAMES Teacher Training Course and Seminar", which is held for the next 10 years in different countries. The e-presentation, the seminar and the teacher training course are published in English.
Finally the "Math-GAMES Testing and Evaluation Report" is published. It is a report about the project, the work, the activities during the lessons, the competitions in schools, the meetings and the evaluation. The Math-GAMES Project Report is published in English. In total the project gives examples of good practice and hints for creating learning courses for using traditional games with normal and lower-skilled people fighting numeracy.
At the end of this project “Math-GAMES - Games And Mathematics in Education for Adults – Compendiums, Guidelines and Courses for Numeracy Learning Methods Based on Games" we have produced 9 compendiums and 9 guidebooks, both are available as printed books and e-books, a website, in which we will present all the material, guidelines for a teacher training course and a detailed report about e.g.:
A big part with a list of different traditional transnational games (photos, game instructions), which can provide social integration. Traditional games can be board games, card games, role plays, acts, folk games involving dramatics, e. g. but not computer games. A general, more theoretical short part about the theme: “Social integration and participation of lower-skilled people by using traditional games”. It should show learners in adult education, how precious it can be to add games in teaching lessons and offer so tailored learning opportunities to individual learners. Some example of best practice from the participating countries and organizations, how lower-skilled people are socially integrated by using traditional games (photos and description of the activity, place and country, effects on the people) Some example of best practice from the participating countries and organizations, how lower-skilled people is getting information on access to lifelong learning services in the local adult education. A description of the origin of games and their symbolic significance, e.g. games about “capture and release”, birth, ritual, etc. Interviews of participating people in their homes, care residences, etc. so that a compendium of authentic testimonies is created. “Games in performance” in front of small audiences of people, who are then given the opportunity to interpret the games and to perform them with the lower-skilled participants on their own, with the participants as audience. Filming, photographing and documentation of parts of the project to upload on our website.
== Materials == From 2016 these materials will be developed: * The Math-GAMES Compendium in 9 languages (BG, DE, EN, ES, FR, GR, IT, RO, TR) is free available from the website www.math-games.eu * The Math-GAMES Guidebook in 9 languages (BG, DE, EN, ES, FR, GR, IT, RO, TR) * The Math-GAMES Teacher Training Course in English * The Math-GAMES Evaluation Report in English
== Literature == * Roland Schneidt(Editor): ''Math-GAMES Compendium''. Verlag Ludwig Schulbuch, Reichertshausen 2016, Germany. {{isbn|978-3-89697-800-4}}
== External links == * [http://www.vmsmedien.de/mathgames/ Homepage of the Math-Games-Project] * [http://www.eaiu.org/ Homepage of the [[EAIU]] - European Association for Intercultural Understanding] * [http://www.vhs-sob.de// Homepage of the Volkshochschule Schrobenhausen e.V.]
[[Category:Education in Europe]]

revision.text:
'''Missouri Research and Education Network''' ('''MOREnet''') is a member-driven consortium, operating as a separate business unit within the University of Missouri. They are primarily made up of Missouri's K-12 schools, colleges and universities, public libraries and government organizations. In addition to maintaining a [[computer network]] for [[Internet]] access to school districts and libraries in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Missouri]]. they also provide technology consulting, a technology help desk as well as professional development and training, consortium discounts and a la carte services by a team of approximately 85 subject matter experts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.more.net/sites/default/files/Annual-Report-Final.pdf|title=MOREnet 2016 Annual Report|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.umsystem.edu/ums/news/news_releases/122309_news | title=John Gillispie appointed executive director of MOREnet | publisher=The Curators of the University of Missouri. | accessdate=20 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.umsystem.edu/ums/news/news_releases/040714_news | title=MOREnet invests and expands fiber infrastructure in southeastern Missouri | publisher=The Curators of the University of Missouri | accessdate=20 October 2015}}</ref>
== History == In 1991, Missouri's four-year public colleges expressed the desire to connect to the NSFnet, a precursor to today's internet. Growth was rapid, but 2002, they connected 509 Missouri public school districts, 64 higher education institutions and 125 tax-supported libraries.
1991: Organization Formed for higher ed primarily to share research electronically
1993:A pilot project with [[Missouri Department of Elementary and Secondary Education]] to include 100 K-12 school districts to include internet connection (which at the time was still an interesting, but unproved concept) as well as hands-on training and technical consultation
1995: The Missouri Secretary of State secured $500,000 for shared online resources available to the entire MOREnet consortium
1997: The MOREnet backbone increased to 45 Mbit/s, which was 30 times faster than the 1993 service
1999: The MOREnet backbone increased to 155 Mbit/s, enabling full-scale interactive video services
2003: The MOREnet backbone increased to 622 Mbit/s
2009: The MOREnet backbone was migrated to a fiber-optic infrastructure to support 10 Gbit/s (10,000 Mbit/s) capacity
2013: Awarded nearly $1 million in grant funding to 3 members for projects designed over a 3-year period to improve outcomes through the adoption of new technologies and STEM based activities, visual learning, business continuity and disaster recovery.
2013: Began a backbone fiber expansion project to bring much needed infrastructure to the un- and under-served region of southeast Missouri
2014: Upgraded network to support up to 100 Gbit/s, making MOREnet one of the first research and education networks in the country to support that speed
== Work Environment == In 2016, MOREnet was recognized for exemplary workplace practices from When Work Works<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.whenworkworks.org/workplace-awards/missouri-research-and-education-network-morenet|title=Workplace Awards: MOREnet|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>, a national initiative, led by the partnership for the Families and Work Institute and the Society for Human Resource Management.
MOREnet practices a modified version of ROWE (Results-Only Work Envioronment). A management strategy used at MOREnet, where employees are evaluated on performance, not presence. In a ROWE, leadership focuses only on results – increasing the organization’s performance while cultivating the right environment for people to manage all the demands in their lives...including work.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.more.net Official website]
[[Category:Educational technology companies]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Missouri]]

revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=November 2011}} [[File:Muza_Rubackyté-Rochemontès.jpg|thumb]] '''Mūza Rubackytė''' (born May 19, 1959) is a [[Lithuania]]n [[pianist]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lrytas.lt/-12275301071225879594-p1-kult%C5%ABra-labdaros-koncerte-gros-pianist%C4%97-m-rubackyt%C4%97.htm|title=Labdaros koncerte gros pianistė M.Rubackytė / Kultūra / lrytas.lt|date=24 November 2008|work=Lietuvos rytas|language=Lithuanian|accessdate=28 February 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029201023/http://www.lrytas.lt/-12275301071225879594-p1-kult%C5%ABra-labdaros-koncerte-gros-pianist%C4%97-m-rubackyt%C4%97.htm|archivedate=29 October 2013|df=}}</ref> currently residing in [[Vilnius]] and [[Paris]]. Rubackytė has been awarded the [[Order of the Lithuanian Grand Duke Gediminas]], Lithuanian Muzes, and has been named as the National Artist of Lithuania.
She holds various teaching positions at a number of educational institutions, including the [[Lithuanian Academy of Music and Theater]] in Vilnius, [[Conservatoire Rachmaninoff]] in Paris, [[Tchaikovsky Conservatory]] in [[Moscow]], Messiaen Academy of Music in the Netherlands. She has also been a judge at the Lithuanian International Piano Competition and International F. Liszt Piano Competition (Utrecht).
A native of Lithuania, Mūza Rubackytė was born into a family of musicians. At the age of 7, she made her professional debut in the capital city of Vilnius performing [[Haydn]]'s ''D Major Piano Concerto'' with the [[Lithuanian National Chamber Orchestra]]. Six years later, she won the first prize in the National Young Artists Competition. The victory opened the doors to the Moscow Tchaikovsky Conservatory, where she studied under [[Yakov Flier]], Mikhail Voskressensky and Bela Davidovitch. During her conservatoire period, she won the first prize in the [[Tallinn]] ([[Estonia]]) Piano Competition and shortly thereafter was awarded the Conservatory's first prize in solo piano, chamber music and accompaniment.
During the Soviet period, Mūza Rubackytė was not allowed to travel outside the [[Communist Bloc]] but performed with orchestras of the [[Baltic states]], [[Ukraine]], [[Armenia]], [[Uzbekistan]], [[Kazakhstan]] and [[Belarus]], as well as the great ensembles of [[Moscow]], [[Vilnius]] and [[St. Petersburg]]. She has lived in Paris since 1991.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://filharmonija.lt Lithuanian National Symphony Orchestra] * [http://lvso.lt Lithuanian State Symphony Orchestra, official site] * [http://www.muza.fr Mūza Rubackytė homepage] {{Lithuanian National Culture and Arts}}
{{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rubackyte, Muza}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Music educators]] [[Category:Lithuanian classical pianists]] [[Category:Lithuanian women pianists]] [[Category:Recipients of the Lithuanian National Prize]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Lithuanian Grand Duke Gediminas]] [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Musicians from Vilnius]] [[Category:Lithuanian Academy of Music and Theatre faculty]]

revision.comment: +[[Category:Reform in Norway]]; +[[Category:1994 in Norway]]; +[[Category:1994 in education]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=November 2013}} The '''University college reform''' was a [[reform]] throughout [[Norway]] where 98 smaller [[college]]s were transformed into 26 larger [[university college]]s from 1 August 1994. In addition a number of [[fine art]] educations were merged to two National Academies of the Arts, in Oslo and in Bergen.
==Goal and result== The reform gave each [[counties of Norway|county]] their own university college, except for the two [[Agder]] counties, who shared one. Some counties have more than one, with [[Møre og Romsdal]] and [[Nordland]] topping with three each. The university colleges were given the main responsibility for training [[nurses]], [[teacher]]s, preschool teachers, [[engineer]]s and business administrators. In addition a number of other tasks were included in the colleges portfolio.
The goal of the reform, that was initiated by the then [[Minister of Education and Research (Norway)|Minister of Education]], [[Gudmund Hernes]] from the [[Norwegian Labour Party|Labour Party]], was to effectivate the operations at the colleges through [[economy of scale]]. Herned had led the public committee that in 1988 had launched the idea of merging and co locating the colleges. The idea was to use teaching resources dedicated to [[academic administration]] instead to be used for teaching and research.
An evaluation of the reform after five years concluded that reform had not succeeded and that the resulting more efficient operations came from lower state subsidies instead of more efficient operations. It also showed that the reform gave the educational personnel more administrative work.
==Other processes== Two years later the [[Norwegian University of Science and Technology]] was created in [[Trondheim]] after a merger of the [[Norwegian Institute of Technology]] and the [[University of Trondheim]], reducing the number of public colleges and universities in Trondheim from thirteen to two.{{Clarify|date=November 2009}} <!-- HiST is counted here, right? -->
From 2005 university colleges were allowed to convert into [[university|universities]] if they met certain requirements. So far both [[Stavanger University College]] and [[Agder University College]] have converted (to the [[University of Stavanger]] and the [[University of Agder]], respectively). Also [[Bodø University College|Bodø]], [[Buskerud University College|Buskerud]], [[Telemark University College|Telemark]], [[Vestfold University College|Vestfold]], [[Hedmark University College|Hedmark]], [[Lillehammer University College|Lillehammer]] and [[Gjøvik University College|Gjøvik]] have announced that they wish to convert to universities, either by themselves or through [[merger]]s. [[Tromsø University College]] ceased to exist in 2009 as it was incorporated into the [[University of Tromsø]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Education in Norway]] [[Category:University reform]] [[Category:Reform in Norway]] [[Category:1994 in Norway]] [[Category:1994 in education]]

revision.comment: /* Practice */
revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization |name = New Zealand Playcentre Federation |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = NZPF |motto = Whānau tupu ngātahi - Families growing together |formation = 1941 |type = co-operative |status = |purpose = High quality early childhood education - a co-operative whānau/family experience |headquarters = |location = New Zealand |region_served = New Zealand |membership = Parents of children attending |language = |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = http://www.playcentre.org.nz |remarks = }}
'''Playcentre''' is an early childhood education and parenting organisation which operates parent-led early childhood education centres throughout [[New Zealand]] and offers parents the opportunity to gain a Diploma in ''Early Childhood and Adult Education''.<ref>http://www.careers.govt.nz/default.aspx?id0=505&id1=PC9565&id3=8809</ref>
When the first playcentre was opened in 1941 the prevailing philosophy in New Zealand child education was that education did not really start until children entered the formal, disciplinarian, school system. Playcentres instead recognised the value of early child education and specifically the educational value of child-initiated play.<ref name="Pam Cubey">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=mMBt6f4G9agC&lpg=PA144&dq=karori%20playcentre%20history&pg=PA144#v=onepage&q=karori%20playcentre%20history&f=false|title=Young Children Learning Through Schemas: Deepening the dialogue about learning in the home and in the nursery|author=Katey Mairs, and The Pen Green Team|editor=Cath Arnold|publisher=Routledge|year=2013|pages=Chapter 8|isbn=9781136241291}}</ref>
Playcentre is indigenous to New Zealand,<ref>http://www.playcentre.org.nz/history.php</ref> but is now also established in Japan.<ref>http://playcentre.org.nz/news.php?a=118&id=&assocID=&national=</ref>
Their mission is stated as "Whānau Tupu Ngātahi - Families growing together."
==History and spread==
The movement started during the [[Second World War]] to provide a break for mothers as well as means to allow for the social development of the child within a cooperative environment. The first such playcentre was established in 1941 in the [[Wellington]] suburb of [[Karori]].<ref>Densem, A. & Chapman, B. (2000). Learning together: The Playcentre Way. Auckland: New Zealand Playcentre Federation. {{ISBN|0-908609-36-1}} p35</ref> From the start each playcentre was a community driven initiative, organised by parents, utilising existing premises (e.g. church or community halls) and using parents as teachers. This allowed the easy spread of the movement, now encompassing over 450 centres around [[New Zealand]] and explains why they are the dominant provider of early childhood education in rural areas.<ref name="Pam Cubey" />
[[Gwen Somerset]], [[Joan Wood]], Inge Smithells and [[Beatrice Beeby]] were among the founders of the organisation.
The Playcentre model has been copied by groups in other countries, including the Japan Playcentre Association.<ref>http://www8.plala.or.jp/playcentre/</ref>
==Philosophy== Playcentre was instrumental in introducing the concept of education through play and through child-initiated activities to the early childhood setting in New Zealand. This philosophy has since been adopted throughout all New Zealand early childhood education centres through the New Zealand national curriculum for early childhood education, Te Whāriki.<ref>http://www.educate.ece.govt.nz/Programmes/TeWhariki.aspx</ref> They remain a champion of child-led non-structured play as the best form of education in early childhood.
The organisation believes that parents are the first and best educators of their children and children learn best when they initiate their learning through play (child-initiated play). Within the centres children and adults learn alongside each other, in agreement with the socio-cultural model of learning which posits that a child learns best when surrounded by trusted members of his or her community.<ref>http://www.playcentre.org.nz/philosophy.php</ref>
Each playcentre is a cooperative. Parents decide how their centre will run and are responsible for the education of their children. Parents also make decisions giving direction to how their association (regional body) and the New Zealand Playcentre Federation (national body) will run.
==Practice== Children attend half day sessions, no more than 5 times a week. Children from 0 to 6 years, normally in mixed age groups, attend sessions run by parents - a minimum of 1 adult to four children. Parents manage all aspects of each playcentre, including the premises, administration, education of the children and education of themselves.
==Structure== Every centre is part of a regional association. There are currently 33 regional associations,<ref>http://www.playcentre.org.nz/assoc.php</ref> which provide support and training and are governed by their member Playcentres. In turn each association is supported by the national body, The New Zealand Playcentre Federation. The Federation is governed by the associations and provides support to meet the goals of the associations.
Playcentres are chartered early childhood education providers with the New Zealand Ministry of Education. Independent research and audits by the Education Review Office confirm the quality of Playcentre's programmes.
==Adult education programme== Playcentre Education administers the NZQA approved Playcentre Diploma in Early Childhood and Adult Education.<ref>http://www.playcentre.org.nz/education.php</ref> The course assists parents in developing their parenting skills and their ability to facilitate early childhood education in a playcentre setting. The programme also helps members to learn how to work in a cooperative as well as being the training ground for Playcentre adult educators. The adult education programme is delivered at no cost to the learner.
==Notable Playcentre people==
Famous Playcentre alumni include New Zealand's first female Prime Minister, the Rt. Hon. [[Jenny Shipley]],<ref>Laurenson, P and Wylie, L.(2000) Millennium Special Edition: Playcentre People. Playcentre Journal, 109, 17</ref> New Zealand's first female Governor General, Dame [[Catherine Tizard]],<ref>Stover, Sue (Ed). (2003). (Revised edition). Good clean fun: New Zealand’s Playcentre movement. Auckland: New Zealand Playcentre Federation. {{ISBN|0-908609-46-9}} pp 99, 240.</ref> the Olympic gold medallists, [[Caroline Evers-Swindell]] and [[Georgina Evers-Swindell]], Colin Simon <ref>Stover, Sue (Ed).(1998). Good clean fun: New Zealand’s Playcentre movement. Auckland: New Zealand Playcentre Federation. {{ISBN|0-908609-46-9}} pp 122.</ref> (designer of the Christchurch Commonwealth Games [[1974 British Commonwealth Games|1974 games]] - [[Christchurch]], [[New Zealand]] symbol and the Playcentre Logo), and Valerie Burns (Companion of the Queen's Service Order <ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/2487912 |title=Shaped the course of early childhood education |author=Johnson, Alexandra |date=10 June 2009 |work=[[The Dominion Post (Wellington)|The Dominion Post]] |accessdate=3 November 2011}}</ref>).
==Further reading== *Laurenson, P and Wylie, L.(2000) Millennium Special Edition: Playcentre People. Playcentre Journal, 109, pp17–14 *Stover, Sue (Ed). (2003). (Revised edition). Good clean fun: New Zealand’s playcentre movement. Auckland: New Zealand Playcentre Federation. {{ISBN|0-908609-46-9}} pp 99, 240. *Densem, A. & Chapman, B. (2000). Learning together: The Playcentre Way. Auckland: New Zealand Playcentre Federation. {{ISBN|0-908609-36-1}} p35 *http://www.educate.ece.govt.nz/Programmes/TeWhariki.aspx *http://www8.plala.or.jp/playcentre/
==External links== *[http://www.playcentre.org.nz/ New Zealand Playcentre Federation]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Education in New Zealand]] [[Category:Early childhood education]] [[Category:Early childhood education in New Zealand]]

revision.comment: /* License */ replaced 'see also' of previous edit with {{see also|Licentiate (degree)#France}}
revision.text:
'''Post-secondary qualifications''' are qualifications typically studied for after successful completion of [[Secondary education in Mauritius|secondary school]]. In [[Mauritius]], this is usually after successful completion of the [[Higher School Certificate (Mauritius)|Higher School Certificate]] or its equivalent, although select qualifications may permit early school leaving or require additional study. A variety of different post-secondary qualifications are offered in Mauritius.<ref name="Mru2007">{{cite web |url=http://www.poledakar.com/dqaf/index.php?title=Mauritius_2007_ISCED |title=Mauritius 2007 ISCED}}</ref>
==Academic qualifications==
===Degree=== {{main|Academic degree}}
The degree is the primary post-secondary academic qualification obtained, typically at a [[Higher education in Mauritius|higher education]] institution. [[Academic degree]]s offered include the [[Bachelor's degree|Bachelor's]], [[Master's degree|Master's]], and [[PhD]]. Entry requirements for the [[Bachelor's degree]] typically includes a [[Higher School Certificate (Mauritius)|Higher School Certificate]]<ref name="Mru2007" /> with [[GCE Advanced Level|GCE A Levels]] in appropriate subjects. Entry requirements for higher degrees typically include lower degrees.<ref name="Mru2007" />
Qualifications may also be awarded in select programmes upon completion of a programme of study that covers part of a degree programme. A [[Diploma]] may be awarded after two years of undergraduate study; students may then progress onto a Top-up course, or be given advanced standing, to complete an undergraduate degree. A [[Postgraduate Certificate]] may be awarded after the first stage, and a [[Postgraduate Diploma]] may be awarded at the second stage, of postgraduate study; students may then be given advanced standing to complete a postgraduate degree.
[[University of Mauritius]] and [[University of Technology, Mauritius|University of Technology]] are the two main degree-granting institutions in Mauritius. Degrees may also be obtained from foreign institutions, either through study abroad, study at a local centre affiliated to a foreign institution, or distance learning; a number of education and training providers offer foreign academic qualifications to students in Mauritius.
===License=== {{see also|Licentiate (degree)#France}} A License is a three-year undergraduate degree, roughly equivalent to a [[Bachelor's degree]]. Types of License offered may include the License Professionelle (Professional Degree) and the License Technologie (Technical Degree). Select institutions of [[Higher education in Mauritius|higher education]], including the [[Université des Mascareignes]],<ref name="UDMCourses">{{cite web |url=http://www.udm.ac.mu/courses.php |title=Université des Mascareignes Courses}}</ref> offer the License qualification.
==Professional qualifications==
===Nursing qualifications===
====Certificate in General Nursing====
The Certificate in General Nursing is a post-graduate qualification that enables nursing practice.<ref name="NCM" /> The course typically takes one year to complete. The pre-requisite for entry into the course is a [[Higher School Certificate (Mauritius)|Higher School Certificate]] or its equivalent.<ref name="NCM">{{cite web |url=http://ncmauritius.org/ |title=Nursing Council of Mauritius}}</ref>
====Diploma in General Nursing====
The Diploma in General Nursing & Midwifery is a post-graduate qualification that enables nursing practice.<ref name="Mru2007" /><ref name="NCM" /> The course typically takes two years to complete.<ref name="Mru2007" /> The pre-requisite for entry into the course is a [[Higher School Certificate (Mauritius)|Higher School Certificate]] or its equivalent.<ref name="Mru2007" /><ref name="NCM" />
=====Top-Up Diploma in General Nursing=====
The Top-Up Diploma in General Nursing allows holders of the Certificate in General Nursing qualification to progress to the Diploma qualification with [[recognition of prior learning]] at the Certificate level.<ref name="NCM" /> The course typically takes one year to complete.
===Teaching qualifications===
====Teacher's Certificate==== The Teacher's Certificate is a post-secondary qualification that enables teaching in primary schools.<ref name="Mru2007" /> The course typically takes two years to complete.<ref name="Mru2007" /> The pre-requisite for entry into the course is a [[Higher School Certificate (Mauritius)|Higher School Certificate]] or its equivalent.<ref name="Mru2007" />
====Postgraduate Certificate in Education (PGCE)==== {{main|Postgraduate Certificate in Education}}
The [[Postgraduate Certificate in Education]] (PGCE)is a post-graduate qualification that enables teaching in primary or secondary schools.<ref name="Mru2007" /> The course typically takes one year to complete.<ref name="Mru2007" /> The pre-requisite for entry into the course is a [[Bachelor's degree]]. Upon completion of the course, further academic progression may be available to a [[Postgraduate Diploma]] or a [[Master's degree]] in Education.<ref name="Mru2007" />
==Vocational qualifications==
Vocational qualifications are designed to provide [[Vocational education in Mauritius|career and technical education]] in specific fields. They may be studied independently or may be earned as part of an [[Apprenticeship]] Scheme (AS).
===Brevet de Technicien (BT)=== {{See also|Brevet de Technicien Supérieur}}
The [[Brevet de Technicien (Mauritius)|Brevet de Technicien]] (BT), also called the Brevet Technician, is a vocational post-secondary qualification, typically offered in a technical subject. Entry requirements for the Brevet de Technicien are typically a [[School Certificate (Mauritius)|Senior Certificate]] or its equivalent.<ref name="MITDFAQs">{{cite web |url=http://www.mitd.mu/faq.php |title=Mauritius Institute of Training and Development FAQs}}</ref> The course typically takes two years to complete.<ref name="Mru2007" /><ref name="MITDFAQs" /> Subjects for which the Brevet de Technicien may be offered include Batiment (Building Construction), Electronique (Electronics), Electrotechnique (Electrotechnics), Frabication Mechanique (Maintenance and Production Mechanics), and Mecanique Automobile (Automobile Mechanics).<ref name="MITDPoly">{{cite web |url=http://www.mitd.mu/centres.php?tc=lpsgf |title=Lycée Polytechnique Sir Guy Forget}}</ref> The Brevet de Technicien is the Diploma qualification<ref name="Mru2007" /> offered by the Lycée Polytechnique in [[Mauritius]].<ref name="MITDPoly" />
===National Certificate (NC)=== {{See also|National Certificate}}
The National Certificate (NC) is a vocational post-secondary qualification, providing training and education in a particular trade. National Certificate courses are offered at several levels mapped to the [[National Qualifications Framework (Mauritius)|National Qualifications Framework]] (NQF). Entry requirements may vary based on the course. Entry requirements for a National Certificate at Level 3 (NC 3) are generally a [[Form III Certificate]] or completion of Form IV in [[Secondary education in Mauritius|secondary school]], the [[National Trade Certificate Foundation]], or the equivalent.<ref name="Mru2007" /><ref name="MITDFAQs" /> Entry requirements for a National Certificate at Level 4 (NC 4) or Level 5 (NC 5) are generally a [[School Certificate (Mauritius)|School Certificate]] (SC), a [[GCE Ordinary Level|GCE O Level]], a National Certificate at Level 3 in related trades, or the equivalent.<ref name="Mru2007" /><ref name="MITDFAQs" /> The course generally lasts for one to two years, depending on the level and field of study.<ref name="MITDFAQs" /> Students may then progress onto a National Diploma, Diploma, or Higher National Diploma course.<ref name="MITDFAQs" />
===National Diploma (ND)=== {{See also|National Diploma (Mauritius)}}
The National Diploma (ND) is a vocational post-secondary qualification, providing training and education in a particular trade. National Certificate courses are offered at several levels mapped to the [[National Qualifications Framework (Mauritius)|National Qualifications Framework]] (NQF). Entry requirements may vary based on the course. Entry requirements may include a [[School Certificate (Mauritius)|School Certificate]] (SC) or [[GCE Ordinary Level|GCE O Levels]], a [[Higher School Certificate (Mauritius)|Higher School Certificate]] (HSC) or [[GCE Advanced Level|GCE A Levels]], a [[National Trade Certificate]] at a specified level, a [[National Certificate (Mauritius)|National Certificate]] at a specified level, or the equivalent. Work experience may also be considered or required.
===Diploma=== The Diploma is a post-secondary qualification.<ref name="ERICPolyMru">{{cite web |url=http://eric.ed.gov/?id=ED441077 |title=Polytechnic Education in Mauritius}}</ref> Entry requirements for the Diploma typically include a [[Higher School Certificate (Mauritius)|Higher School Certificate]] (HSC), two [[GCE Advanced Level|GCE A Levels]], a National Certificate at Level 4 (NC 4) or Level 5 (NC 5) in related trades, or the equivalent.<ref name="Mru2007" /><ref name="MITDFAQs" /> The course typically takes two years to complete.<ref name="Mru2007" /><ref name="MITDFAQs" /> Successful completion of the Diploma allows for progression onto the Higher National Diploma.<ref name="Mru2007" />
===Higher National Diploma (HND)=== {{See also|Higher National Diploma}}
The Higher National Diploma (HND) is a post-secondary qualification. Entry requirements for the Higher National Diploma typically include a [[Higher School Certificate (Mauritius)|Higher School Certificate]] (HSC), two [[GCE Advanced Level|GCE A Levels]], a National Certificate at Level 4 (NC 4) or Level 5 (NC 5) in related trades, a Diploma in a related subject, or the equivalent.<ref name="Mru2007" /><ref name="MITDFAQs" /> The course typically takes two to three years to complete.<ref name="Mru2007" /><ref name="MITDFAQs" />
Higher National Diploma courses offered in Mauritius educational institutions are typically awarded by [[Edexcel]] [[Business and Technology Education Council|BTEC]] with accreditation in the [[United Kingdom]]. A BTEC Higher National Diploma is roughly equivalent to two years of undergraduate degree-level study at a university. Upon successful completion, students may gain admission to [[Bachelor's degree]] programmes, typically with two years of advanced standing. This enables those who entered the vocational stream to re-enter the academic stream and progress further in higher education.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Education in Mauritius}}
[[Category:Education in Mauritius]]

'''June 12, 2018''': 1 ([https://twitter.com/ABSCBNNews/status/1006437273628360705?s=20 ref]) | detentions = 1'''May 1, 2017''': 1 ([http://news.tv5.com.ph/police/watch/iC8QD-cpZH4/miyembro%20ng%20kadamay,%20naaktuhang%20gumagamit%20ng%20droga ref]) | charged = | fined = | casualties_label = | notes = | sidebox = {{Rodrigo Duterte sidebar}} }} The '''protests against [[Rodrigo Duterte]]''', the [[List of Presidents of the Philippines|16th]] [[President of the Philippines]], began on November 18, 2016 following the [[Burial of Ferdinand Marcos|burial of late president Ferdinand Marcos]], whom Duterte supported.{{cite news|title=Millennials lead protests vs Marcos burial|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/845960/millennials-lead-protests-vs-marcos-burial|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer.|date=November 20, 2016}} These series of protests are conducted by several [[Left-wing politics|left]] and [[Right-wing politics|right-wing]] groups and other opponent figures mainly due to ongoing war on drugs in the country and other administration issues. == Protests == [[File:Mongolian Prime Minister Jargatulgyn Erdenebat and Duterte (cropped).jpg|President Rodrigo Duterte|left|thumb|160px]] === War on drugs and extrajudicial killings === {{Main|Philippine Drug War|Extrajudicial killings and forced disappearances in the Philippines}} Since his inauguration on June 30, Duterte implemented the war against illegal drugs in the country, promising to kill thousands of people involved in the drug trade.[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jul/01/philippines-president-rodrigo-duterte-urges-people-to-kill-drug-addicts "Philippines president Rodrigo Duterte urged people to kill drug addicts"]. [[Associated Press]]. July 1, 2016. Retrieved July 8, 2016 – via ''[[The Guardian]]''.[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-drugs-duterte-idUSKCN11B0TK?feedType=RSS&feedName=topNews "Obama throws planned meeting with Philippines leader into doubt…"]. [[Reuters]]. This campaign has been the subject of heavy criticism by local politicians and international human rights, as well as the [[Western world|Western]] media, due to human rights violations and high number of killings amid drug campaign.[http://www.rappler.com/nation/146535-european-parliament-philippines-end-wave-extrajudicial-killings "European Parliament urges PH: End wave of killings"]. ''Rappler.''[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/rodrigo-duterte-eu-f-you-expletive-philippines-attack-parliament-obama-a7319836.html "Philippines president Rodrigo Duterte tells the EU 'F***you' over his war on drugs"]. ''The Independent.'' The youngest known person killed in the drug operation is the 17-year-old student, [[Shooting of Kian delos Santos|Kian Loyd delos Santos]], from [[Caloocan]], on August 16, 2017.{{cite news|title=17-year-old student gunned down by cops in anti-drug operations|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2017/08/18/Kian-Loyd-Delos-Santos-war-on-drugs-Caloocan-police-operations.html|work=[[CNN Philippines]]}} The killing sparked the controversy among the local politicians and militant groups, and triggered massive protest in the country.{{cite news|title=17-year-old's death jolts senators to speak vs killings|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/08/18/1730393/17-year-olds-death-jolts-senators-speak-vs-killings|work=[[The Philippine Star]]}} The family of Delos Santos, on August 25, filed murder and torture charges against police officers involved in the drug operation.{{cite news|title=Murder, torture raps filed vs. police over Kian's death|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2017/08/25/Kians-kin-files-murder-torture-raps-vs.-Caloocan-police.html|work=[[CNN Philippines]]}} As of mid-2018, the death toll of war against drugs reached 4,251 dead,{{notetag|Despite this, the number was disputed by opposition Senator [[Antonio Trillanes]], who asserts that the number of deaths are 20,322 (as of February 2018). The total number Trillanes had includes by adding 3,967 drug personalities who died in anti-drug operations (November 27, 2017 data) and 16,335 homicide cases under investigation (September 30, 2017 data).{{cite news |title=Trillanes calls on Senate to defend De Lima, press freedom, right to life |url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/196573-trillanes-privilege-speech-de-lima-press-freedom-extrajudicial-killings |work=[[Rappler]]}} Another source is from [[Human Rights Watch]], which claims that 12,000 died in the drug war, as of January 2018.{{cite news |title=Philippines: Duterte's 'Drug War' Claims 12,000+ Lives |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2018/01/18/philippines-dutertes-drug-war-claims-12000-lives |work=[[Human Rights Watch]]}}}} according to the police.{{cite news |title=PNP bares numbers: 4,251 dead in drug war |url=https://www.philstar.com/headlines/2018/05/08/1813217/pnp-bares-numbers-4251-dead-drug-war |work=[[The Philippine Star]]}} {{hidden |Locations of protests against Duterte in [[Metro Manila]] |{{OSM Location map | coord={{coord|14.5682|121.0169}} | zoom =11 | float=left | width = 250 | height = 365 | shape1=n-circle | shape-color1=blue | shape-outline1=white | mark-size1=16 | mark-coord1 = {{coord|14.579824|120.984489}} | mark-title1 = [[Supreme Court of the Philippines]] | mark-coord2 = {{coord|14.598611|120.991667}} | mark-title2 = [[Mendiola Street]] | mark-coord3 = {{coord|14.6|121.06}} | mark-title3 = [[People Power Monument]] | mark-coord4 = {{coord|14.592222|121.058611}} | mark-title4 = [[EDSA Shrine]] | mark-coord5 = {{coord|14.652790|121.058424}} | mark-title5 = [[University of the Philippines Diliman]] | mark-coord6 = {{coord|14.580035|120.973834}} | mark-title6 = Quirino Grandstand | caption = |Locations of protests against Duterte | auto-caption=1 }} }} === Burial of Ferdinand Marcos === {{Main|Burial of Ferdinand Marcos}} {{See also|History of the Philippines (1965–1986)|Proclamation No. 1081}} [[File:0040jfVigils demonstrations Media coverages Ferdinand Edralin Marcos Burial Cases Judgmentfvf 02.jpg|thumb|left|230px|Protesters opposing the burial of Marcos.]] During [[Rodrigo Duterte presidential campaign, 2016|his 2016 presidential campaign]], Duterte supported the burial of late President and dictator [[Ferdinand Marcos]] at the [[Heroes' Cemetery]] in [[Taguig]].[http://www.rappler.com/nation/politics/elections/2016/123061-duterte-marcos-burial-libingan-bayani "Duterte in Ilocos Norte: I will allow Marcos' burial in Heroes' Cemetery"]. [[Rappler]] On November 8, 2016, the [[Supreme Court of the Philippines|Supreme Court]] permitted Marcos' burial in a 9–5–1 vote.{{cite news|last1=Cabacungan|first1=Gil|title=SC votes, 9-5, for burial of Marcos at Libingan|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/842372/sc-votes-9-5-for-burial-of-marcos-at-libingan|accessdate=January 8, 2018|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=November 9, 2016}} Marcos was buried at the Heroes' Cemetery on November 18.{{cite news|last1=Guinto|first1=Joel|title=Late dictator Marcos buried at Libingan ng mga Bayani|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/11/18/16/late-dictator-marcos-buried-at-libingan-ng-mga-bayani|accessdate=January 8, 2018|publisher=ABS-CBN News and Current Affairs|date=November 18, 2016}} Following his burial, protests — organized by, mostly, youths from various universities, militant groups and local politicians — sparked in the whole country.[http://news.mb.com.ph/2016/11/08/sc-allows-marcos-burial-at-the-libingan-ng-mga-bayani/ "SC ‘allows Marcos burial at the Libingan ng mga Bayani’]. [[Manila Bulletin]].[http://www.rappler.com/nation/152813-ferdinand-marcos-heroes-burial "Marcos to be buried at Heroes' Cemetery today"]. Rappler.[http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2016/11/08/vp-senators-disappointed-supreme-court-decision-marcos-burial.html "VP, senators disappointed and sad as Supreme Court allows burial in hero's cemetery for Marcos". CNN Philippines.][http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/589352/news/nation/drilon-on-marcos-burial-a-thief-even-in-death "Drilon on Marcos burial: A thief even in death". GMA News.] === Phasing out of jeepneys === A series of protest and [[strike action]] staged by [[jeepney]] drivers in the Philippines to oppose the government's plan to phaseout jeepneys over 15 years old. The strike, which started on February 6 and 27, caused hundreds of passengers to be stranded.{{cite news |last=Pascual |first=Jekki |title=Libo-libo, stranded dahil sa tigil-pasada kontra jeepney phaseout |url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/video/news/02/06/17/libo-libo-stranded-dahil-sa-tigil-pasada-kontra-jeepney-phaseout | work=[[ABS-CBN News]] |location= |date=February 6, 2017 |access-date=February 27, 2017 }}{{cite news |last= |first= |title=Jeepney drivers to hold strike Monday |url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/02/25/17/jeepney-drivers-to-hold-strike-monday | work=[[ABS-CBN News]] |location= |date=February 25, 2017 |access-date=February 27, 2017}} As a result of protests, classes in the country were suspended, as well as the government work.{{cite news |last= |first= |title=Class cancellations for Monday, February 6, 2017 |url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/598451/news/metro/class-cancellations-for-monday-february-6-2017 | work=[[GMA News]] |location= |date=February 6, 2017 |access-date=February 27, 2017 }}[http://www.sunstar.com.ph/manila/local-news/2017/10/15/no-classes-govt-work-nationwide-oct-16-569489 "No classes, gov't work nationwide on Oct. 16"]. ''Sun.Star''[http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/nation/601097/class-cancellations-for-monday-feb-27-2017/story/ "Class cancellations for Monday, Feb. 27, 2017"]. Transport groups resumed the protests on September 24{{cite news|title=Transport strike vs jeepney modernization set for September 25|url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/183204-transport-strike-stop-and-go-coalition-september-24|work=[[Rappler]]}} and October 14 to 16.{{cite news|title=EXPLAINER: What's the reason for the 2-day transport strike?|url=https://www.rappler.com/newsbreak/iq/185435-explainer-philippines-transport-strike-october-2017|work=[[Rappler]]}} On October 18, 2017, Duterte said that on January 1, next year, "If you can't modernize that, leave. You're poor? Son of a bitch, go ahead, suffer in poverty and hunger, I don't care."{{cite news|title=Duterte to jeepney drivers: Modernize or else…|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/938800/duterte-to-jeepney-drivers-modernize-or-else|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]}} However, [[Land Transportation Franchising and Regulatory Board]] (LTFRB) chairman Martin Delgra said the next day that Duterte's call was only his "expression of urgency".[https://web.archive.org/web/20180117054025/http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/nation/630095/duterte-s-deadline-to-upgrade-jeepneys-only-an-expression-of-urgency-delgra-says/story/ "Duterte’s deadline to upgrade jeepneys only ‘an expression of urgency,’ Delgra says"]. Archive from the [http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/nation/630095/duterte-s-deadline-to-upgrade-jeepneys-only-an-expression-of-urgency-delgra-says/story/ original]. ''GMA News''. Its proposal of jeepney modernization will displace 270,000 jeepneys nationwide and around 650,000 drivers and it costs up to P1.6 million. In January 2018, an operation called "''Tanggal Usok, Tanggal Bulok''" was implemented by Inter-Agency Council for Traffic (I-ACT) for the dilapidated and smoke belching jeepneys.{{cite news|title=LTFRB readies city buses for backup amid "Tanggal Usok, Tanggal Bulok" campaign|url=https://www.untvweb.com/news/ltfrb-readies-city-buses-for-backup-amid-tanggal-usok-tanggal-bulok-campaign/|work=[[UNTV (Philippines)|UNTV News]]}}[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4La5r-x3DeI "250 PUVs flagged down in campaign vs old vehicles, smoke belchers"]. [[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] — via [[YouTube]]. However, its commuters gave a difficult time in riding jeepneys, particularly the students.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Odgr-vo1xA8 "Bandila: Mga pasahero, walang masakyan dahil sa pagtatanggal ng bulok na PUV"] (in Tagalog). [[ABS-CBN News and Current Affairs|ABS-CBN News]] — via [[YouTube]].
Interviews at 0:25-35.
'''Student 1''': ''"Medyo, mahirap talaga tapos sumakay talaga."''
'''Student 2''': ''"..., pasehero yung naapektuhan, at syempre pati yung [mga] drivers."''
'''Student 3''': ''"Masyado... Konti yung kasi mga jeep."'' Commuters expressed their frustration on social media for apprehending the jeepneys that causes the commuters to be stranded. === "Walk for Life" === The "Walk for Life" was a [[mass demonstration]] organized by the [[Catholic Bishops' Conference of the Philippines]] (CBCP) protesting the reintroduction of the [[death penalty in the Philippines|death penalty]] and call for an end to killings amid the country's ongoing "war on drugs". On February 18, 2017, the march gathered approximately 20,000 [[Filipinos|Filipino]] [[Catholic]]s in [[Manila]]. The church had led the revolutions that successfully toppled former Presidents [[Ferdinand Marcos]] in [[People Power Revolution|1986]] and [[Joseph Estrada]] in [[Second EDSA Revolution|2001]].{{cite news|title=Philippine Church in 'show of force' against drug killings|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/600092/news/nation/philippine-church-in-show-of-force-against-drug-killings|work=GMA News}} Among those who joined the rally was Senator [[Leila de Lima]], a critic of Duterte who opposes the war on drugs.{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/tens-thousands-filipino-catholics-protest-against-death-penalty-dutertes-drug-war-1607241|title=Tens of thousands of Filipino Catholics protest against death penalty and Duterte's drug war}} On January 30, 2017, the CBCP issued a statement opposing the revival of the death penalty.{{cite news|title=CBCP: We can work with administration|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/871173/cbcp-we-can-work-with-administration|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer}} CBCP President [[Socrates Villegas]] called on the Filipino people to join a rally, which the CBCP had called a "Walk for Life", opposing the killings amid the country's war on drugs. On February 24, 2018, thousands of people joined at the [[Quirino Grandstand]].[http://news.abs-cbn.com/video/news/02/24/18/thousands-join-walk-for-life-vs-death-penalty-summary-killings "Thousands join 'Walk for Life' vs death penalty, summary killings"]. ''[[ABS-CBN News and Current Affairs|ABS-CBN News]]''. === Kadamay housing project protests === {{Main|Kadamay housing project protests}} On March 8 to April 4, 2017, an urban poor group Kadamay (''Kalipunan ng Damayang Mahihirap'') led an occupation in the 5,000 idle housing in [[Pandi, Bulacan]],{{cite news |title="#OccupyBulacan - Urban poor group vows to continue barricade in gov’t housing projects". |url=http://bulatlat.com/main/2017/03/14/occupybulacan-urban-poor-group-vows-continue-barricade-govt-housing-projects/}} and eventually slamming Duterte for not giving the house to the poor.{{cite news |title=SANAY NANG TINATAKOT - Grupong Kadamay, hindi raw matitinag sa banta ni Pres. Duterte |url=http://news.tv5.com.ph/breaking/tuloy-ang-laban-grupong-kadamay-hindi-raw-matitinag-sa-banta-ni-pres-duterte |work=[[News5]]}} === Declaration of martial law following Marawi crisis === {{Main|Battle of Marawi|Proclamation No. 216}} [[File:Lakbayan 2017 Kampuhan sa Diliman protest.jpg|left|thumb|Anti-martial law, anti-[[American imperialism|imperialist]] calls by indigenous peoples and Moro people during the [[Lakbayan ng Pambansang Minorya|Lakbayan 2017]]]] A five-month-long armed conflict in [[Marawi]], [[Lanao del Sur]], that started on 23 May 2017, between [[Government of the Philippines|Philippine government]] [[Armed Forces of the Philippines|security forces]] and militants affiliated with the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL), including the [[Maute group|Maute]] and [[Abu Sayyaf]] [[Salafi jihadism|Salafi jihadist]] groups.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/05/25/1703153/marawi-crisis-what-we-know-so-far |title=Marawi crisis: What we know so far |work=[[The Philippine Star]] |date=25 May 2017 |accessdate=25 May 2017}} The battle also became the longest [[urban warfare|urban battle]] in the modern history of the Philippines.{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/939202/marawi-war-maute-terrorism-duterte-isnilon-hapilon-is-islamic-state|title=Marawi: City destroyed in Philippines' longest urban war|publisher=Inquirer News|date=19 October 2017|accessdate=19 October 2017}} Following the clash, Duterte declared [[Martial law in the Philippines|martial law]] in the whole [[Mindanao]].[http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2017/05/24/Duterte-declares-martial-law-in-Mindanao.html "Duterte declares martial law in Mindanao"]. [[CNN]]. === State of the Nation Address protests === ==== July 24, 2017 ==== Several groups led the protest on the day of President Duterte's second [[State of the Nation Address (Philippines)|State of the Nation Address]] (SONA). According to Renato Reyes, secretary general of Bayan, the president's promises of improvements during [[2016 State of the Nation Address (Philippines)|his first SONA]] still remained unfulfilled, including issues on [[Contractual term|contractualization]], land reforms, and economic policy.{{cite news|title=Malawakang kilos protesa ihihahanda na ng iba't-ibang grupo sa araw ng SONA|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AFhcFQLrR8Q|issue=UNTV News and Rescue via [[YouTube]]}} Reyes also said that, "Under his administration, regularization has already happened: It is now regular to kill drug suspects, regular to sabotage peace talks, regular to militarize, and regular to spread fake news and disinformation."{{cite news|title=Protesters hit Duterte's 'wrong regularization'|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/917212/protesters-hit-dutertes-wrong-regularization|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]}} Also, labor unions [[Kilusang Mayo Uno]] and Alyansa ng mga Manggagawa Laban sa Kontraktwalisasyon led similar protests, calling "to resume peace talks and to end martial law in Mindanao."{{cite news|title=Groups prepare for SONA protests|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2017/07/23/Protesters-prepare-for-SONA-rally.html|work=[[CNN Philippines]]}}[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DiVy6s1Gr00 "NTG: Mga militante, nagkikilos-protesta na vs. administrasyong Duterte; may mga dala ring effigy"] (in Tagalog). [[GMA News and Public Affairs|GMA News]] — via [[YouTube]]. About 5,000 members of Bagong Alyansang Makabayan from [[Roxas City]], 3,000 in [[Iloilo City]], 2,500 in [[Kalibo]], 500-800 in Cebu City, and 500 in [[Estancia, Iloilo]] joined the protest, concerning an end to contractualization, land reform, free education and jeepney modernization.{{cite news|title=Protesters at 2nd Sona not as friendly|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/916537/protesters-at-2nd-sona-not-as-friendly|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer}} Also, about 300 [[Lumad]] people joined the protest, calling to stop the martial law.{{cite news|title=300 'Lumads' join protest during Duterte's 2nd Sona|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/917110/300-lumads-joint-protest-during-dutertes-2nd-sona|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer}} At midnight, around 100 anti-Duterte protesters held a candle vigil, led by [[Senate of the Philippines|Senator]] [[Risa Hontiveros]], condemning the extrajudicial killings and extension of martial law in Mindanao. Hontiveros called Duterte's second SONA a "fake".{{cite news|title=Anti-Duterte protesters, nagsagawa ng candle lighting vigil sa Batasan Hills, QC|url=https://www.untvweb.com/videos/anti-duterte-protesters-nagsagawa-ng-candle-lighting-vigil-sa-batasan-hills-qc/|issue=UNTV}} At night, Duterte confronted the protesters for the first time.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qtrpGqAT300 "Bandila: Duterte, hinarap ang mga raliyista matapos ang SONA"] (in Tagalog). [[ABS-CBN News and Current Affairs]] — via [[YouTube]]. ==== July 23, 2018 ==== [[File:SONA 2018.jpg|thumb|State of the Nation Address mobilization 2018|left]] [[File:Protest art SONA 2018.jpg|thumb|Protest art during State of the Nation Address 2018|left]] Ahead of [[2018 State of the Nation Address (Philippines)|Duterte's third State of the Nation Address]], opposition lawmakers announced that they will wear protest [[Barong Tagalog|Barongs]] with artwork.{{cite news |title=Look: Opposition solons to wear 'protest barongs' for People's SONA |url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/07/22/18/look-opposition-solons-to-wear-protest-barongs-for-peoples-sona |accessdate=July 23, 2018 |work=ABS-CBN News}} Opposition figures—such as Senators [[Antonio Trillanes|Antonio Trillanes IV]], Risa Hontiveros, and [[Bam Aquino]]—attend the mass at the University of the Philippines Diliman. There, Bishop Broderick Pabillo said on the sermon that the proposed [[Federalism in the Philippines|federalism]] and the [[Constitutional reform in the Philippines|charter change]] are not the solution of wiping out the problem in the country.{{cite news |title=lang miyembro ng oposisyon, nakiisa sa 'Misa para sa bansa |url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/video/news/07/22/18/ilang-miyembro-ng-oposisyon-nakiisa-sa-misa-para-sa-bansa |work=ABS-CBN News}} On the day of SONA, over 6,000 police officers will deploy in different areas in Metro Manila to secure the SONA.{{cite news |title=Over 6,000 cops, 600 soldiers to secure 2018 SONA |url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/206951-number-police-soldiers-secure-duterte-sona-2018 |work=[[Rappler]]}} Dubbed the protest as "United People's SONA,"{{cite web |title=Thousands join protests against Duterte’s SONA |url=https://www.untvweb.com/videos/thousands-join-protests-against-dutertes-sona/ |website=[[UNTV (Philippines)|UNTV News and Rescue]] |accessdate=July 25, 2018}} different groups coalitions and organizations held a protests on the day of Duterte's third State of the Nation Address nationwide.{{cite news |title=In Photos: Thousands hold SONA 2018 protests around PH |url=https://www.rappler.com/move-ph/208000-sona-2018-protests-philippines-photos |accessdate=July 24, 2018 |work=[[Rappler]]}}{{cite news |title=List: SONA 2018 activities, protests |url=https://www.rappler.com/move-ph/207793-sona-2018-philippines-activities-protest |work=[[Rappler]]}} Bayan Muna Southern Tagalog featured Duterte's effigy and then burned it.{{cite news |title=Watch: Bayan Muna southern Tagalog rallyists burn "Dutertemonyo" effigy. {{!}} via Mon Jocson |url=https://www.facebook.com/UNTVNewsRescue/videos/2620128494679214/ |work=[[UNTV (Philippines)|UNTV News and Rescue]]|via=[[Facebook]]}}{{cite news |title='Duterte-monyo': Protesters parade effigies depicting Duterte as evil |url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/focus/07/23/18/duterte-monyo-protesters-parade-effigies-depicting-duterte-as-evil |work=ABS-CBN News}} Demonstrators gathered at University of the Philippines Diliman, slamming the series of killings in the country and the increase of basic goods due to [[Tax Reform for Acceleration and Inclusion Act]] (TRAIN law) while some considering to "Oust Duterte."{{cite news |title=Activists protest killings, rising prices ahead of SONA |url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/07/23/18/activists-protest-killings-rising-prices-ahead-of-sona |accessdate=July 23, 2018 |work=ABS-CBN News}} Gabriela, in Commonwealth Avenue in front of Tandang Sora flyover, also slammed Duterte by bearing the messages in the tarpaulin, "Manyakis," "Dutertambay,", "Bomba King," and "Endoterte."{{cite news |title=SONA 2018: Women’s groups to protest in thousands against Duterte |url=https://untvweb.com/news/sona-2018-womens-groups-to-protest-in-thousands-against-duterte/ |accessdate=July 23, 2018 |work=UNTV News}} In [[Bicol Region|Bicol]], militant groups also held a rally.{{cite news |title=Rallies in Bicol mark Duterte’s 3rd Sona |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/1013137/rallies-in-bicol-mark-dutertes-3rd-sona |work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]}} Meanwhile, Pro-Duterte groups also gathered in Batasan Road.{{cite web |title=Look: Pro-Duterte groups from Caloocan City are set to march to Batasan Road for their program. {{!}} via Aiko Miguel |url=https://www.facebook.com/UNTVNewsRescue/posts/2620194564672607 |publisher=UNTV News and Rescue|via=[[Facebook]]}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20180723061413/https://www.facebook.com/UNTVNewsRescue/posts/2620194564672607 Archive] from the original. === Anniversary of Martial Law protests === {{multiple image | align = left | image1 = 2324National Day of Protest Plaza Miranda, Quiapo, Manila 25.jpg | width1 = 240px | image2 = 2324National Day of Protest Plaza Miranda, Quiapo, Manila 29.jpg | width2 = 240px | footer = Supporters of Duterte gathered at the front of the [[Quiapo Church]] during the National Day of Protest. }} On September 21, 2017, nationwide protests — also known as "National Day of Protest" — are conducted by various groups against the government's implementation of war on drugs and the ongoing martial law in the whole of Mindanao under the Duterte administration, as part of the commemoration of the 45th anniversary of the declaration of martial law in 1972 by late President Marcos.{{cite news|title=Thousands join national protest to remind Filipinos of Marcos' Martial Law|url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/182868-philippines-protest-rallies-martial-law-45th-anniversary|work=[[Rappler]]}}[https://www.rappler.com/move-ph/182923-in-photos-nationwide-protests-45th-anniversary-martial-law "In Photos: From Luzon to Mindanao, a day of protest vs return of martial law"]. ''Rappler'' As the day of protest approaching, [[Malacañang Palace]] released Duterte's Proclamation No. 319 and Memorandum Circular no. 26 on this day.{{cite news|title=Palace issues proclamation on National Day of Protest|url=http://news.mb.com.ph/2017/09/20/palace-issues-proclamation-on-national-day-of-protest/|work=[[Manila Bulletin]]}} A Memorandum Circular no. 26 states that government offices and public schools at all levels are suspended. Duterte said that he will not condone any means of violence committed by protesters.{{cite news|title=Only gov't work, classes in public schools are suspended on Sept. 21|url=http://news.mb.com.ph/2017/09/20/only-govt-work-classes-in-public-schools-are-suspended-on-sept-21/|work=[[Manila Bulletin]]}}{{cite news|title=Duterte officially declares September 21 as 'National Day of Protest'|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/manila/local-news/2017/09/20/duterte-officially-declares-september-21-national-day-protest-565103|work=SunStar Philippines}} Duterte even dared the communist [[New People's Army]] "to bring the protests to Manila, as he vowed not to arrest them."{{cite news|title=Sept. 21 National Day of Protest—Duterte|url=http://thestandard.com.ph/news/top-stories/247312/sept-21-national-day-of-protest-duterte.html|work=The Standard}} [[File:174National Day of Protest Mendiola San Miguel, Manila 27.jpg|thumb|left|230px|Protesters at Mendiola]] Left-wing activists and opposition of Duterte accused him of abuses and [[authoritarianism]] similar to that of Marcos.{{cite news|title=Watch {{!}} National Day of Protest: Activists warn against emergence of dictatorship|url=http://www.interaksyon.com/national-day-of-protest-activists-warn-against-emergence-of-dictatorship/|work=[[News5]]}} [[Vice President of the Philippines|Vice President]] [[Leni Robredo]] states that "If we do not remember the past, we are condemned to repeat it. Sadly those who are deceived do not even know that they are walking a doomed path."{{notetag|Robredo's quote appeared to be derived from the writer and philosopher [[George Santayana]]'s original quote.{{cite web |title="Those who do not learn history are doomed to repeat it." Really? |url=https://bigthink.com/the-proverbial-skeptic/those-who-do-not-learn-history-doomed-to-repeat-it-really |publisher=Big Think}}}} In [[Plaza Miranda]], about 500 pro-Duterte rallyists occupied in front of the [[Quiapo Church]].{{cite news|title=Update: PH holds 'National Day of Protest'|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/update-ph-holds-national-day-protest/351893/|work=[[The Manila Times]]}} [[Teddy Casiño]] said to Duterte that "he is the subject of the protest", after the latter declares September 21 a day of protest.{{cite news|title=Pro-Duterte, anti-Martial Law groups engage in chant battle on Mendiola|url=https://www.rappler.com/move-ph/182926-martial-law-45th-anniversary-duterte-supporters-mendiola-plaza-miranda|work=[[Rappler]]}} Pro and anti-Duterte rallyists also engaged in chant battle. A group of pro-Duterte supporters are seen elsewhere in the city, calling to stop the "destabilization," which is rumored to be made by the opposition.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a5CcrDBOGWY "BT: Mga tagasuporta ni Pres. Duterte, may kilos-protesta rin"] (in Tagalog). [[GMA News and Public Affairs|GMA News]] — via [[YouTube]]. On September 21, 2018, nationwide protests are conducted, marking the 46th anniversary of Martial Law. These protests are mainly conducted by several groups such as Youth Act Now Against Tyranny and Bagong Alyansang Makabayan.{{cite news |title=Schedule: 46th Martial Law anniversary protests, activities |url=https://www.rappler.com/move-ph/212418-schedule-martial-law-anniversary-protest-activities-september-21-2018 |accessdate=September 21, 2018 |work=[[Rappler]]}} They also featured the menacing artworks of Duterte, along with former President and now [[Speaker of the House of Representatives of the Philippines|House Speaker]] [[Gloria Macapagal Arroyo]] and Ferdinand and [[Bongbong Marcos]]. Also, removed Chief Justice Maria Lourdes Sereno also present at the event. Liberal Party members held the event by mass. Meanwhile, pro-Duterte supporters also held the demonstration.{{cite news |title=SONA: Paggunita sa ika-46 anibersaryo ng martial law, idinaan ng mga militanteng grupo sa protesta |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LY1S9CsuQ8M |accessdate=September 24, 2018|publisher=[[GMA News and Public Affairs|GMA News]]|via=[[YouTube]]|language=Tagalog}} Other groups featured the pile of buckets with the pictures of Duterte, the Marcoses, newly-appointed Chief Justice [[Teresita de Castro]] and other Duterte's cabinet — parodying the milk brand [[Alaska Milk Corporation|Alaska]], which was then being [[Tumbang preso|toppled by the slippers]].{{cite news |title=Bandila: Anibersaryo ng batas militar ni Marcos, ginunita sa Luneta |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0BrWywQO5Ss |publisher=[[ABS-CBN News and Current Affairs|ABS-CBN News]] |language=Tagalog|via=[[YouTube]]}} ''Note: View from 0:15–0:27 for the bucket being toppled.'' (At the start of the video) ''"Julius, nagsimula ang tensyon ng punahin ang ilang dumalo sa rally ang isang litrato na inilagay sa higanteng tumbang preso. Kinuwestyon ng mga lalaki kung may mukha ni dating Pangulo [Benigno] "Noynoy" Aquino sa mga pinatutumbang timba na may mga mukha rin nina Pangulong Marcos, Arroyo, at Duterte. Hiniling ng mga lalaki na alisin ng timba na may mukha ni Aquino bilang respeto. Ayon sa grupong Dakila, pinaliwanag nila sa mga lalaki na hindi pa rin kasi umano natutugunan ang mga problema sa Pilipinas kahit magbago ang namumuno."'' Some protesters questioned the inclusion of former President [[Benigno Aquino III]]'s face in the bucket, whom the organizers said that because of unsolved problems in the country. They later removed Aquino's face in the bucket as a respect. === "Lord, Heal Our Land" === On November 5, 2017, the [[Catholic Church in the Philippines|Catholic Church]] held a prayer rally and healing mass along the [[EDSA (road)|EDSA]] highway, the site of the People Power Revolution, to oppose the extrajudicial killings. The procession was attended by around 3,500 people.{{cite news|last1=Jalea|first1=Mary Gleefer|title=EDSA prayer rally held vs extrajudicial killings|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/edsa-prayer-rally-held-vs-extrajudicial-killings/360881/|accessdate=January 12, 2018|work=The Manila Times|date=November 5, 2017}} CBCP president and Lingayen-Dagupan Archbishop [[Socrates Villegas]] said: {{quote|Let us ask that our prayers for the country's healing be answered. The November 5 activity has no colors. It will stand for transparency, clarity of vision, purity of heart. We won't be there to shout and hold a rally. We will pray and whisper to Jesus' heart to ask for forgiveness, forgiveness for the country that sinned."{{cite news|title=No politics, just prayers for healing in Edsa rally|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/943026/no-politics-just-prayers-for-healing-in-edsa-rally|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]}}}} Administration opponent groups such as Movement Against Tyranny and Tindig Pilipinas were present at the event. They clarified that the event was to only express frustration, not the "destabilization."{{cite news|title='Lord Heal Our Land' an expression of frustration, not destabilization — organizers|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/nation/632003/lord-heal-our-land-an-expression-of-frustration-not-destabilization-organizers/story/|work=GMA News}} Opposition politicians such as Senators [[Bam Aquino]], [[Franklin Drilon]], Risa Hontiveros[http://videos.inquirer.net/?tracked=true&categoryID=all&videoid=1030498&video_title=senators_join_edsa_march_to_push_for_end_to_drug_killings___&pfrm=template "Senators join Edsa march to push for end to drug killings"]. ''Philippine Daily Inquirer.'' and [[Antonio Trillanes]] were also present. === 2017 ASEAN Summit and Trump's visit to the Philippines === [[File:Fascist Spinner.jpg|thumb|Activists burn rotating Trump effigy, dubbed as "Fascist Spinner," inspired by the [[fidget spinner]].]] Protests erupted from November 9—14, 2017, thousands staged the protest against the [[ASEAN Summit|Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit]] hosted by the Philippines.{{cite news|title=Violence marks ASEAN 2017 protests in Manila|url=https://www.rappler.com/move-ph/188511-violence-protests-asean-summit-2017-philippines|work=[[Rappler]]}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20171110151600/https://www.rappler.com/move-ph/187955-schedule-protest-activities-asean-summit-2017 "Schedule: Protest activities during ASEAN Summit 2017"]. ''[[Rappler]]''. Archived from the [https://www.rappler.com/move-ph/187955-schedule-protest-activities-asean-summit-2017 original]. Their call was to ban the visit of [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Donald Trump]], who visited the country to attend ASEAN-related summits as a dialogue partner.{{cite news|title='Not welcome in PH': Filipino activists set fire to Trump effigy|url=https://www.rappler.com/move-ph/188275-filipino-activists-set-fire-trump-effigy-asean-2017-philippines|work=[[Rappler]]}} It is because, according to student leader Elijah San Pedro, Trump seemingly "to have dragged the Philippines into his [[North Korea and weapons of mass destruction|war rhetorics]] against [[North Korea]]."{{cite news|title=Why groups are protesting Trump's PH visit|url=https://www.rappler.com/move-ph/188098-groups-protes-trump-visit-asean-summit}} Atty. Aaron Pedrosa of SANLAKAS also said that [[Mamasapano clash|Mamasapano massacre]] and the war in Marawi were created by the U.S.-led [[War on Terror]]. Karapatan Alliance for the Advancement of People's Rights slammed the Trump administration for "'funding' the administration's war on drugs." The [[Philippine Coast Guard]] reported that protesters attempted to bribe fishermen to get them close to the [[Embassy of the United States, Manila|United States Embassy]].{{cite news|last1=Talabong|first1=Rambo|title=Philippine Coast Guard to arrest ASEAN Summit protesters at Manila Bay|url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/187977-asean-2017-arrest-protesters-manila-bay-philippine-coast-guard|accessdate=January 11, 2018|publisher=Rappler|date=November 10, 2017}} A group of protesters led by Anakbayan managed to reached the gate of [[Philippine International Convention Center]], despite tight security.{{cite news|title=Small group of ASEAN summit protesters reach PICC gate|url=https://www.rappler.com/move-ph/188108-protesters-asean-summit-picc-gate|work=[[Rappler]]}} Militant group Kalipunan ng Damayang Mahihirap (Kadamay) also staged protests against Trump.[https://www.rappler.com/move-ph/187979-asean-budget-basic-social-services-poor-kadamay "'P15-B ASEAN summit budget should have gone to the poor' – Kadamay"]. ''[[Rappler]]''.[http://www.philstar.com/nation/2017/11/10/1757558/activists-picket-us-embassy-ahead-trump-visit "Activists picket US Embassy ahead of Trump visit"]. The Philippine Star. A group said that the {{Philippine peso|15.5-billion}} ($292 million) budget of the ASEAN Summit could have been used for the poor.[https://www.rappler.com/move-ph/187979-asean-budget-basic-social-services-poor-kadamay "'P15-B ASEAN summit budget should have gone to the poor' – Kadamay"]. Rappler. Aside from Trump, protesters also burned the images of [[Prime Minister of Australia|Australian Prime Minister]] [[Malcolm Turnbull]], [[Prime Minister of Japan|Japanese Prime Minister]] [[Shinzō Abe]], [[President of Russia|Russian President]] [[Vladimir Putin]], and [[Premier of the People's Republic of China|Chinese Premier]] [[Li Keqiang]], whom "protesters said are responsible for the anti-Filipino and [[Imperialism|imperialistic]] agenda allegedly promoted by the Duterte administration."[http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2017/11/13/protest-donald-trump-asean.html Militant groups clash with police in anti-Trump rally"]. [https://web.archive.org/web/20171119020527/http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2017/11/13/protest-donald-trump-asean.html Archived] from the original. CNN Philippines. Anti-riot police used water cannon and [[Sonic boom|sonic alarm]] to repel activists.{{cite news|title=In Photos: At least 2,000 attend protests on day one of ASEAN Summit|url=https://www.rappler.com/move-ph/188299-photos-protesters-asean-summit-2017-philippines-day-one|work=[[Rappler]]}} [[Bagong Alyansang Makabayan]], led by Renato Reyes, have the Trump's effigy — with four rotating hands shaped into the [[swastika]] symbol and President Rodrigo Duterte can be seen behind — burned. Despite being fired by the water cannon, the protesters continue to push forward against the blocking police.{{cite news|title=Anti-riot cops block protesters|url=http://tempo.com.ph/2017/11/14/anti-riot-cops-block-protesters/|work=Tempo}} It is reported that 20 members of militant groups were injured after engaged the clash with the police.{{cite news|title=Update: Anti-Trump protesters, cops clash; militants claim 20 injured|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/asean-summit-protesters-cops-clash/362436/|work=[[The Manila Times]]}} Trump arrived in the country on November 12.{{cite news|title=Trump arrives in PH for ASEAN Summit|url=https://www.rappler.com/world/regions/asia-pacific/188127-trump-arrival-asean-philippines|work=[[Rappler]]}} === Proposed revolutionary government === On October 2017, Duterte said that he would declare a [[Revolutionary government in the Philippines|revolutionary government]] against the supposed conspirator of destabilizing the government made by the [[Communism in the Philippines|communist rebels]], Liberals and other factions.{{cite news|title=Can Duterte declare a revolutionary government?|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/10/24/1750739/can-duterte-declare-revolutionary-government}}{{cite news|title=Rody threatens to declare revolutionary gov't if...|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/10/14/1748619/rody-threatens-declare-revolutionary-govt-if...|work=[[The Philippine Star]]}} He said to the media that "'''Pag ang'' (if the) ''destablization ninyo patagilid na at medyo magulo na'' (would be shaky and more trouble), I will not hesitate to declare a revolutionary government until the end of my term." The next month, he clarified that he would only declare a revolutionary government if "things go out of control."{{cite news|title=Revolutionary gov't remark not an outright statement, Duterte insists|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/11/19/1760428/revolutionary-govt-remark-not-outright-statement-duterte-insists|work=[[The Philippine Star]]}} Should the revolutionary government declared, "he would order the security forces to arrest all destabilizers and go on a full-scale war against communist rebels." Duterte draws criticism from the opposition, stating that the declaration is a beginning of the stage towards his [[dictatorship]].[http://www.manilatimes.net/duterte-revolutionary-govt/363787/ "Duterte: What revolutionary govt?"]. ''[[The Manila Times]]''. On November 30, as part of the celebration of [[Bonifacio Day]], a protest was held, condemning the revolutionary government threat.[https://www.untvweb.com/news/revolutionary-government-meant-establish-duterte-dictatorship/ "‘Revolutionary government’ meant to establish Duterte dictatorship"]. ''[[UNTV (Philippines)|UNTV News]]''. On the other side, around thousands of Duterte supporters gathered at [[Mendiola Street|Mendiola]], urging Duterte to declare a revolutionary government.{{cite news|title=Watch: Declare revolutionary government, supporters urge Duterte|url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/190034-declare-revolutionary-government-supporters-urge-duterte-november-30-2017-rally-mendiola|work=[[Rappler]]}} Presidential spokesperson Harry Roque advised the pro-revolutionary government supporters "to conduct their rallies in a peaceful, orderly manner."{{cite news|title=Palace: Duterte rejects revolutionary gov't but supporters can hold peaceful rally|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/11/30/1763960/palace-duterte-rejects-revolutionary-govt-supporters-can-hold-peaceful}} Harry Roque also said that "The president has earlier said that he does not want a revolutionary government. This, however, does not mean he would prevent citizens from expressing their support for a revolutionary government." === Black Friday Protest for Freedom === [[File:Defend Press Freedom.jpg|thumb|#DefendPressFreedom Black Friday mobilization]] National Union of Journalists of the Philippines staged a protest, dubbed as "Black Friday Protest for Freedom", in Quezon City and other parts of the country such as [[Bacolod]] and [[Zamboanga City]] on the evening of January 19, 2018,{{cite news|title=Palace: 'Black Friday' protest shows freedom, democracy alive|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2018/01/19/1779322/palace-black-friday-protest-shows-freedom-democracy-alive|work=Philippine Star|issue=January 19, 2018}}[http://www.sunstar.com.ph/bacolod/local-news/2018/01/20/journos-militant-groups-join-black-friday-protest-584839 "Journos, militant groups join ‘Black Friday’ protest"]. SunStar Philippines{{cite news|title=Bacolod media, groups join 'Black Friday' call to uphold press freedom|url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/194075-bacolod-join-black-friday-call-press-freedom|work=[[Rappler]]}} following the revocation of online news site [[Rappler]] by [[Securities and Exchange Commission (Philippines)|Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC) eight days prior.[http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2018/01/15/sec-revokes-rappler-license-to-operate.html "SEC cancels Rappler's license to do business"].
